Hello, thanks for doing this. As someone interested in anthropology myself, it's good to see anthropologists out there!

I'm wondering what your thoughts are on the relationship between far-right extremist ideology and religious fundamentalism in the US, especially the heavy focus on the eschatological elements of American Christianity. Some parts of the QAnon movement certainly echo some variety of messianism, and that's basically never gone well for anyone involved.

It seems to me that a lot the reasons that people give for their opinions are confabulation.  It's not that they are lying, rather it is that don't actually know why they believe what they believe.

I'll give two examples.  Trump supporters say that the Trump is the legitimate president because election fraud result in an illegitimate win for President Biden.  But this is not actually why they think the election is illegitimate.  

Trump supporters believe the election was stolen because Trump won the white vote.  In their "tacit" view, America is a white country and "real" Americans are white.  If the winner of the presidential election did not get a majority of votes from "real" Americans, the vote cannot be legitimate.  

I think that this logic is largely unconscious.  Almost like our tacit knowledge of grammar produces a sentence without our necessarily understanding why the words are arranged as they are, our unconscious ideas about race and identity produce results we then confabulate reasons for.

A second example is abortion.  Abortion opponents claim that person-hood is established at the moment of conception, and this is why abortion should be a crime.  But this is not the reasoning that they actually use, as the IVF case shows.  IVF inevitably produces unusable fertilized eggs that must eventually be destroyed, but abortion opponents are in favor of allowing this to happen but not abortion on demand. Why?

The difference between the cases is the intention of the mother, not the professed person-status of the fetus.  IVF involves women who want to be mothers, while most abortions cases are the reverse.  Anti-abortion efforts are meant to target (punish) women who are sexually active but do not want to  be mothers.  So IVF is okay, but abortion on demand is not, and the person-hood of the fetus doesn't enter into it all.

I raise the question of coherence in political reasoning because I suspect that political reasoning is, in fact, coherent, even if the reasons people give are not.  This is relevant to the question of political violence and extremism because we often rationalize violence and extremism with incoherent arguments.  

Unmasking the tacit beliefs that underpin political violence could be one means of pushing back against it because the tacit reasons are tacit *for* a reason. The tacit reasons are in some way ego-alien and threaten the coherence of the person's identity by conflicting with other beliefs. And that could force a change.

As former president [Donald Trump struggled last month to post a bond for more than $450 million](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/03/18/trump-civil-fraud-judgment-bond-450-million/?itid=lk_inline_manual_2) to keep authorities from seizing his properties, California billionaire Don Hankey and his wife, Debbi, started discussing a solution: Hankey’s business could cover it.

Hankey, a Trump supporter who made a fortune providing high-interest auto loans to customers with poor credit, soon reached out to Trump’s team to negotiate a deal that would allow Trump to stay the penalty while he appealed a massive New York civil fraud judgment. But when a court reduced the bond to $175 million last week and Trump said he had the cash to post it himself, the matter seemed moot, Hankey told The Washington Post.

Then, to his surprise, the Trump team last week revived the talks and asked Hankey if he would back the new amount. Hankey promptly agreed. He said that his company is charging Trump a “modest fee,” which he declined to disclose, and that the arrangement allowed Trump to hold onto his money, adding, “At least he’s getting interest on his collateral.”

With [the bond, which Trump posted Monday](https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2024/04/01/trump-new-york-bond-175-million/?itid=lk_inline_manual_8), Hankey appears to have facilitated a final step in Trump’s narrow escape from a cash crunch that a few weeks ago had the New York attorney general vowing to come after his assets and experts wondering if he would have to file for bankruptcy as he faced more than half a billion dollars in penalties from two civil cases, with only weeks to find the money.

The financial boost for the presumed GOP nominee has thrust Hankey into the midst of a presidential campaign, bringing a new national profile to a colorful 80-year-old worth $7.4 billion, according to Forbes, who worked his way from car salesman to major player in the car loan industry and owner of Xanadu, formerly Olivia Newton-John’s Malibu estate. If Trump is elected, their relationship could come under new scrutiny if the government is involved in matters affecting Hankey’s business.
